It's important to recognize that we have an obligation--I have an obligation in particular--to stop people coming into this country who could get young people in particular to behave in the kind of appalling way we saw in July and that we want to ensure that those who foment, justify, glorify terrorism are not able to be in this country.
Joining us is Jonathan Freedland.
He's a columnist for London's Guardian newspaper.
Jonathan, welcome back to the show.
And just what are these new criteria?

Now if you are a foreign national living in Britain and you are held to be not only inciting directly acts of terrorism but if you are in any way in a speech or a sermon or a Web site justifying or glorifying acts of terror, then you are not welcome and can be deported.
And it's particularly aimed at the people who the tabloid newspapers here have dubbed the preachers of hate.

There is a group, very small, a handful of clerics from abroad who have set up shop here in Britain and are fiery in their rhetoric and deliver sermons full of bluster and fire--in one speech calling those people who staged 9/11 magnificent; others talking about the people who did the London bombings in July as praiseworthy.
That will now not just be a kind of rhetoric which appalls people but which will now be an actionable offense and enough to get you booted out of the country.
These are Islamic clerics speaking at particular mosques in London and elsewhere.
They've been the subject of a lot of coverage.
In the past, the government has said, `You know, it's better to have these people speaking at these mosques where we can at least listen to what they say and know where they are.
It's actually safer to do things this way,' but the government doesn't seem to believe that anymore.

Well, Tony Blair's phrase before he took off for his vacation was, `The rules of the game are changing,' and that has been repeated by his Home secretary--a kind of interior minister, homeland security minister--Charles Clarke.
There weren't many people who would have put as frankly as you did the previous logic, which is `At least we know what they're saying.

It was also seen as being--and I think many people still do believe this--that it was just inevitable; in a free society, there are going to be people saying things you don't like, and that that was going to be the price you pay.
But now there is this change in the mood, and one of my reservations about this plan is I'm not sure it's really getting at the whole of the problem.
Some of these most incendiary of Muslim clerics are actually British-born, British citizens.
And it's not quite clear what the law is going to do for them.
It's not possible just to beat people out of the country.
So does it become a jailable offense?
Probably not.
What will probably happen under these new proposals is that they will be subject to so-called control orders.
Now these--this is a notch below a felony.
It means you don't go to trial; you don't get punished or convicted and punished.
What happens instead is you are placed under huge restrictions, a kind of house arrest.
Those will probably be the measures applied in the next tranche of government steps to British-born nationals.

What the government has said is that you must embrace the traditional British value of tolerance for others and you can't be leading people to be intolerant, but surely there would be some people there in Britain who are saying it's the government's policies that are now intolerant, increasingly less tolerant.
Indeed, the prime minister's wife, Cheri Blair, has argued that you can't go so far in this anti-terrorist fight as to endanger civil liberties.
This is the ancient, age-old liberal dilemma: How much should you tolerate the intolerant?
It's interesting you mentioned the prime minister's wife.
She is the center of another part of the controversy.

If these rules about justifying and validating terrorism are indeed extended to those people who are born in this country, many people, myself included, have pointed out that the prime minister may find himself prosecuting his own wife.
Cheri Blair said two or three years back that she fully understood suicide bombers, Palestinian suicide bombers in Israel, who had, in her words, no choice but to turn themselves into human bombs.
Now if the--if all people are equal before the law, surely that would count as justifying terrorism.
That's one problem.
Another problem with these foreign nationals who would be deported, it's one thing to be deport people.
There's no, in principle, problem with that.
But they're going to be deported almost certainly to countries that have a very patchy record on human rights, and some of whom are--have been accused of torture.
Now it is against the European Convention on Human Rights, to which Britain is a signatory, to send the people knowingly to face that fate.

So these people may have the most repulsive views you could imagine, but if you are sending them off knowing that they are going to be tortured in Syria, Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, etc., that contravenes Britain's own undertakings on human rights.
That, at least, is the view of the civil libertarians.

An opinion poll of my own newspaper, the Guardian, this week said that three-quarters of British people do not have these reservations and believe that you have to suspend some civil liberties in order to be safer from terror.
Do you think you are seeing the beginnings of a change in the British national character because of these bombings in July?
It's very possible.
I would say that, actually, it's one of the myths that Britain tells itself about how proud it is of its own liberties.
It--actually, Britain has constantly allowed some of its civil liberties to be taken away.
So I think it's one of these things--we've already changed.
I don't think we've got too much innocence to lose.

Valmeyer, Illinois, just South of St. Louis was completely under water 15 years ago.
After that disaster, town leaders decided to move the entire community high atop a nearby bluff.
NPR's Kathy Lohr, who visited the town in 1993, went back to see how the new location is working out.
It's not hard for people here in Valmeyer to recall the summer of 1993.
The worry, the fear, the moment when they knew the Mississippi had ripped through a levee and gushed inside their town.
Some 18 feet of water stood in the business district and in many homes.
Residents had been fighting hard, and were discouraged they couldn't keep the water out.
Former Mayor Dennis Knobloch took me on a tour of the town 15 years ago just after the water had receded.
You can see all the clocks are stopped at the bewitching time of 1:20.
That's when I gave the signal to the power company to go ahead and shut the power off in town when we knew that there definitely was a levee break and the water was going to be coming.
So, that's when the town went black.
(Soundbite of bird chirping)
Well, still probably the most eerie thing that was part of what I had to do.
Standing in the same spot, Knobloch, who's now county clerk, still gets nostalgic when he thinks about it.
You know it's one of those little things that probably doesn't mean a whole lot to a lot of other people, but you know that's when it all stopped here.
While that was the end of the old Valmeyer, it was the beginning of years of work to move the town 400 feet to the top of a bluff, to an area that was once farmland.
When I last saw the new Valmeyer back in 1994, it was a mass of red dirt roads and construction trailers.
We joke about it, it seemed like we went from 1993 to 1995, and we don't even remember what happened in 1994.
Howard Heavner is Valmeyer's current mayor.
He also teaches agriculture at the local school.
It was a challenge keeping the town together.
School was held in trailers on the county fair grounds.
The post office was 10 miles away, and construction was moving very slowly.
We wanted things to happen now, and all those things just seem like they took forever.
Mayor Heavner went to the school that was flooded when he was a kid, but you can tell he is proud of the new brick building where about 500 students attend kindergarten through the 12th grade.
As we head into the office, long-time school secretary Mary Murtins(ph) acknowledges how important it was to rebuild the school.
The school is just part of the main focus, I guess, in a lot of small towns.
If it hadn't had a school, who knows?
About half of Valmeyer's residents did not move back, including Mary Murtins.
It wasn't that she didn't like the new location, but rebuilding took too long.
So we chose to move to Waterloo, and at the time we were able to move or buy some ground out in the country, and we built a house there.
The constant delays and government red tape were among the toughest challenges to putting this community back together.
The total cost: about 45 million dollars, with the local community paying about 10 million of that.
Valmeyer adopted the slogan, rising to new heights, and 15 years later, it has three churches, two banks, a gas station, daycare center, and tavern.
The town also has attracted 300 new residents.
